Award.AbstractNarration: ABSTRACT<br/>Dissertation Institute<br/><br/>The lack of diversification of engineering faculty poses serious threats to the replacement of an aging engineering faculty, the retention of underrepresented minority students, the development of a diverse workforce, and the well-being of the nation. While there have been many initiatives to increase the representation of underrepresented minority faculty, systematic efforts have not been designed to address the completion of doctoral degrees amongst this population. Data show that students, particularly underrepresented students, are leaving before obtaining a degree because of the long, arduous, and uncertain road to graduation. These data also suggest that individuals, graduate schools, and society would benefit from efforts to reduce time-to-degree and degree completion rates. Therefore, the primary goal of this project is to offer a practical and timely experience particularly for underrepresented doctoral students in engineering (African American, Native American, Pacific Island and Hispanic American) to address issues germane to shortening time-to-degree and degree completion rates. The specific aims are to: 1) conduct research to understand the motivational factors that promote and detract from degree progress and 2) to develop and offer the Dissertation Institute (Institute) to provide underrepresented doctoral students in engineering with motivating, helpful strategies for avoiding pitfalls that prolong completion times, particularly those at the dissertation proposal preparation and dissertation completion stages. Current efforts to support underrepresented doctoral students have tended to be local opportunities within specific programs or universities. This project is different from existing efforts because it will systematically examine and positively impact the motivational factors that promote dissertation completion across multiple sites to consider and incorporate contextually relevant factors such that the Institute is transferable across contexts and not limited to local implementation. This transferability is critical to developing a sustainable future program to support underrepresented students. This project addresses strategic goals of the National Science Foundation (NSF) and critical needs of the nation related to enhanced global competitiveness and an improved national economy.<br/><br/>This project is grounded in the expectancy-value theory of motivation and will result in two sets of outcomes: research outcomes and direct benefits to participants. Using quantitative and qualitative research methods, the research outcomes will include: 1) contextually relevant and nationally representative research-based data we can use to inform the Institute's design regarding the success beliefs and values that contribute to and detract from students' dissertation success, 2) measures of Institute effectiveness in terms of participant's increased beliefs about succeeding in and the value of completing a dissertation, and 3) a list of variables to which academics should pay attention when designing transferable versions of the Institute. To achieve the outcomes of our study, we have designed a multi-method, multi-phased study. We will examine and draw on stakeholder needs to develop an Institute that is consistent with literature suggestions and effective practices but also contextually relevant for participants. Finally, we will comparatively analyze the data across sites to allow us to identify the key elements on which we should focus in considering transferability of the Institute to additional sites and/or through online means. The research will directly impact approximately 170 underrepresented doctoral students and will contribute to the long-term sustainability of other Institute models. In addition to improving basic writing habits and skills, Institute participants will gain practical strategies for: 1) distinguishing between behaviors that foster or hinder success, 2) increasing engagement in positive behaviors and eliminating destructive behaviors, 3) developing plans to maneuver through the dissertation phase from selecting a topic to completing the dissertation, and 4) establishing realistic program completion goals and plans for implementing those goals. As a result of participation, students will gain specific skills in synthesizing and evaluating findings from the literature to aid in developing a dissertation proposal or for writing a dissertation. They will learn how to identify helpful, credible resources (people, physical and online) and how to use them effectively. Participants will also learn about developing and writing conference papers and publishable manuscripts from the dissertation, an important part of being ready for future employment. In combination, the project outcomes will have immediate impacts on participants while setting the stage for longer-term benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Dissertation Institute (DI) is a program grounded in Situated Expectancy-Value Theory (SEVT) created by a research team for a multi-year NSF-funded project. The DI offers a practical and timely experience intended to help minoritized doctoral students in engineering, including computer sciences, to develop sustainable skills to complete their dissertation and shorten their time to degree. During the years from 2017 to 2023, the project team hosted six DI.  Four were in person and two were virtual due to the COVID-19 pandemic.  During that time, approximately 161 students from backgrounds considered underrepresented in engineering disciplines attended.  Over the six years, the project team gathered research and evaluation data (surveys, interviews, and observations) guided by SEVT principles and based on the premise that finishing a Ph.D. requires significant individual motivation, and this motivation is impacted by the cultural and academic contexts. Analysis of data from across the project revealed that the DI had a positive impact on students? success beliefs, value beliefs, and overall motivation to complete the degree.  Specifically, the DI activities (workshops, writing clusters, and practicing writing) helped participants engage in their academic writing and recognize the value of their doctoral degree.  Additionally, participants in the first two DI expressed a need to have an experience like the DI earlier in their doctoral journey.

Data collected over the six (6)-year project revealed the following key findings:

  1. Project Leadership identified that the unique combination of three (3) specific components (instruction provided through workshops, protected time for writing, and accountability sessions after writing time) resulted in the formation of a community for participants that ultimately addressed issues specific to time-to-degree and eventual graduation.
  2. Prior student participants emphasized that the value they gained from the Dissertation Institute had both an immediate and long-term positive impact in that they were able to achieve real-time progress with their writing efforts while participating in the Dissertation Institute and continued to build on it after completing the Dissertation Institute.

The results from this summative evaluation provided evidence that the Dissertation Institute discovered the contextual differences that were important to consider with regards to transferability of the Dissertation Institute for future sustainability to a significant extent. Student participants consistently echoed the appreciation they had for the entirety of the Dissertation Institute experience from the workshop provision to dedicated working time, to the Writing Cluster sessions. It was the combination of these experiences that ultimately resulted in support and creation of a community for students who often lacked this sense of community at their specific academic institutions. This (creation of a community provided with instruction and protected time) led to the contextual specificity required for the Dissertation Institute to have a positive and lasting impact on student participants.

The results from this summative evaluation provided evidence that the Dissertation Institute has a significant impact on student success beliefs, value beliefs, and time-to-degree completion. Results from pre, post, and ex-post assessments throughout all six (6) years of the project showed that in general, positive differences were observed when comparing pre- to post-survey results or post to ex-post survey results. The larger story of the Dissertation Institute was also told when reviewing themes from the follow-up interviews and looking at data from the Dissertation Institute Impact survey administered to the alumni (all past DI recipients). Specifically, beyond seeing differences when measuring specific constructs in surveys, students also self-reported differences in their belief that they could be successful in their dissertation journey. Most noticeably, students reported these differences 6-8 months past their Dissertation Institute experience as well as years past their experience. Students directly credited the Dissertation Institute with providing them specific skills and the opportunity to practice those skills within a community of their peers and assigned advisors as being a reason why they were able to be successful in their doctoral journey.

Using student feedback, the Rising Dissertation Institute (RDI) was designed and piloted in the fourth year of the overall DI project.  The RDI had the following goals: (1) provide a timely orientation for rising doctoral students about preparing themselves to start graduate school, (2) create a mentoring network where minority graduate students at proposal and dissertation phases (DI participants) can mentor rising doctoral students, and (3) conduct research to understand the intersection of minority undergraduate students' understanding about graduate education and their motivations to pursue a graduate degree.  Based on successful piloting, a larger-scale RDI project has been launched.  The DI won a  CONECD Program of the Year award.
